attributes.title: Choice, Cognition, and Affect during the 2020 COVID-19 Pandemic
attributes.description:
The 2020 COVID-19 Pandemic is an unprecedented event inducing similarly-unprecedented levels of chronic, sustained stress and anxiety on a global scale; thus, the downstream effects of these affective responses on behavior are currently unknown. Previous characterizations of stress and its effects on cognitive performance, using lab inductions of acute stress and measurements of naturally-occurring chronic stress, are arguably of a different magnitude than the intense stress and anxiety induced by the pandemic, due to its life-or-death, quickly changing, pervasive and uncontrollable nature. The current moment is thus a unique opportunity to understand how intense, real-world stress and anxiety influence fundamental cognitive processes, including the ability to flexibly allocate mental resources using cognitive control, and the evaluation of risk and basic construction of value. Understanding how these cognitive abilities and behaviors shift during a pandemic could provide crucial, missing, and foundational information about the human mind and brain under severe stress. Characterizing such effects could prove crucial to the development of strategies, interventions, and policies that address, account for, and mitigate changes in individuals’ choices and cognitive performance in response to intense, real-life, stressors. 

To study this, we are conducting an experiment on Pavlovia, where U.S.-based participants complete both laboratory-quality behavioral tasks and self-report surveys. In particular, participants will complete a risky decision-making task (Sokol-Hessner et al., 2016) dissociating and quantifying risk attitudes, loss aversion, choice consistency, and context effects, and a cognitive control task measuring proactive versus reactive control (an AX-CPT paradigm; adapted from Gonthier et al., 2016). Performance in both of these tasks has been shown to shift in response to affective and stress influences (e.g., risky decision-making: Sokol-Hessner et al., 2009, 2015a, 2015b, 2016; AX-CPT: Chiew & Braver, 2013, 2014; Yang, Miskovich, & Larson, 2018), but these effects have typically been characterized in the laboratory using experimentally-induced manipulations of affect and stress. In the present study, we propose to examine shifts in decision-making and controlled performance as a function of pandemic-related stress, which we will characterize using a combination of subjective self-report measures and objective measures indexing pandemic progression using epidemiological data. In addition to behavioral task performance, we will obtain self-reported measures of state and trait anxiety, perceived stress, subjective loneliness, and perceptions of the pandemic and its personal risk. Demographic measures including age, gender identity, socio-economic status, and state and county location will also be measured.

Importantly, we will recruit a sample stratified by state and associated pandemic progression (measured using epidemiological data from state and federal public health agencies) and propose to collect participant data in two phases. In Phase 1, we will collect data every 24 hours over a 20-day period, enabling us to examine whether and how task performance and psychological measures shift across participants as the pandemic progresses over time. Pending funding, Phase 2 will commence immediately after Phase 1 (i.e., 20 days after commencing data collection in Phase 1). Phase 1 participants will be invited to re-enroll in the study and complete task and self-report measures again. Re-enrolled participants will take part in Phase 2 following their participation in Phase 1 as closely as possible (i.e., if a participant was recruited and participated on Day 4 of Phase 1, we will aim to re-enroll them and have them participate on Day 4 of Phase 2).

q2.value:
We will test how pandemic-related stress, as indexed by self-report measures of anxiety, stress and loneliness, as well as pandemic-related events like changes in the number of confirmed infections or deaths from state and federal databases, are associated with changes in choice and cognitive performance. Specifically, we will test the following predictions. 

Risky decision-making: We will test the hypothesis that pandemic-related stress will be associated with no net effect on risk attitudes (risk aversion or risk seeking) but decreased loss aversion. We expect no net effect on risk aversion on the basis of mixed prior findings. On the one hand, increased risk aversion was found following the chronic administration of cortisol over 8 days (Kandasamy et al 2014), while another, larger study measuring chronic levels of naturally occurring cortisol on a scale of months found no consistent change (Chumbley et al, 2014). The literature on the effects of acute stress on risk aversion is also mixed, with laboratory studies finding that risk aversion increased (Porcelli & Delgado, 2009), decreased (Pabst et al 2013), and did not change (Sokol-Hessner et al 2016) as a function of acute stress responses. We expect decreased loss aversion on the basis of prior findings indicating that higher chronic levels of cortisol on a scale of months are linked with reduced loss aversion (Chumbley et al, 2014). Our task will additionally enable us to separate any possible effects of chronic, pandemic-related stress on risk attitudes and loss aversion from those on choice consistency. Finally, in our recent research, we have identified strong effects of previous outcomes on subsequent risk-taking that cannot immediately be explained by learning (Brooks & Sokol-Hessner, in revision). Because these findings are so recent, it is not yet known how stress may alter such integrative processes. We will thus explore the effects of stress on temporal context effects in risky monetary decision-making by examining whether the effects of past outcomes on risk taking vary as a function of stress. 

AX-CPT performance: We will test the hypothesis that pandemic-related stress, as indexed by both pandemic progression and self-report measures of anxiety, stress, and loneliness, will be associated with a decrease in proactive cognitive control (poorer AY trial performance) in the AX-CPT. This hypothesis is formulated on the basis of prior findings of declining context maintenance and proactive control as a function of both anxiety (Fales et al., 2008; Yang, Miskovich, & Larson, 2018) and anticipation of punishment (Braver et al., 2009). Importantly, there are two possible hypotheses we will test regarding reactive control under stress on the basis of prior evidence. While a number of studies (including Braver et al., 2009; Yang et al., 2018) demonstrated an increase in reactive control concurrent with a decrease in proactive control, these modes of control have been argued to operate independently instead of being necessarily inversely correlated (Chiew & Braver, 2017). Given additional observations that cognitive flexibility, which has been argued as analogous to reactive control, decreases under acute, laboratory-induced stress manipulations (Plessow et al., 2011), we will thus also test the hypothesis that reactive control (indexed by BX trial performance) will decline in addition to proactive control.

q3.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: We have a within-subjects design. All participants will take part in a risky decision-making task where behavioral performance will be analyzed following prior work (Sokol-Hessner et al., 2016; Brooks & Sokol-Hessner, in revision) examining risky decision-making as a function of pandemic stress and prior context. All participants will also take part in a cognitive control task (the AX-CPT) enabling separate metrics of proactive and reactive control, which will be analyzed as a function of pandemic stress.

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Using Pavlovia.org, we will collect data from a U.S.-based online sample over a 20-day period (Phase 1) followed by a second 20-day period during which time Phase 1 participants are invited to participate a second time (Phase 2). 

Importantly, we will collect data from a sample stratified by pandemic progression. Using information about COVID-19 case numbers in each state (obtained from usafacts.org), we will assign each state to either the first, second, third, or fourth quartile of states in terms of number of COVID-19 cases on the day of data collection commencement. An equal number of participants from each quartile will be recruited each day for 20 days in Aim 1. We will invite Aim 1 participants to take part again in Aim 2, with their recruitment in Aim 2 timed to follow Aim 1 as closely as possible (i.e., if a participant was recruited and participated on Day 4 of Phase 1, we will aim to re-enroll them and have them participate on Day 4 of Phase 2).

q11.value: We will recruit 560 participants into Phase 1 of the study (28 participants, or 7 participants per quartile, taking part on each day of the study for 20 days) and attempt to recruit as many Phase 1 participants as possible to return for Phase 2.

q12.value: Using G*Power3, we estimated that to detect a small effect size (f^2 = .02) with 90% power and alpha = .05 in a linear multiple regression with four predictors (two-tailed), we need a sample of 528 participants. We based our estimates on the assumption of a small effect given lack of precedent for this event in the existing stress and cognition literature.

q13.value: We aim to collect N=28 per day for 20 days in Phase 1 of the study and will re-enroll as many of our Phase 1 participants into Phase 2 as possible. Given the time-sensitive nature of the study (20 days in Phase 1 and 20 days in Phase 2), we will stop recruiting participants each day when the day time-window is over.

question.value:
Measured variables to be used in confirmatory analyses: 

Risky decision making task: Probability of selecting the risky option, computation model parameters (e.g. loss aversion, risk attitudes, choice consistency, decision bias, context effects).
AX-CPT task: accuracy rates and reaction times as a function of task condition (AX, AY, BX, BY trials) 
Pandemic progression: for each participant, calculated on the basis of state and county location (number of cases and number of deaths on the day of participation)
State and trait anxiety (measured using the State-Trait Anxiety Inventory) 
Perceived stress (measured using the Perceived Stress Scale)
Loneliness (measured using the UCLA Loneliness Scale) 

Measured variables to be used in exploratory analyses: 

Social contact questions: 

How many people did you physically see on an average day in January? "Physically see" is defined as getting within 10 feet of someone without any barriers between you and them.
On an average day in January, how many people were you interacting with (rating each of the following individually): in person; by video chat; by phone; by email; by text; by social media
How many people do you physically see on an average day now? "Physically see" is defined as getting within 10 feet of someone without any barriers between you and them.
On an average day now, how many people are you interacting with (rating each of the following individually): in person; by video chat; by phone; by email; by text; by social media

Perception of and behaviors toward the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic: 

Please rate the overall level of risk to you personally that you perceive from the COVID-19 pandemic. (1-9 scale; 1=none, 9=extreme) 
How much of a threat do you think COVID-19 (coronavirus) is? (1-7 scale; 1=not a threat at all, 7 = extremely threatening)
 How likely do you think it is that you yourself will die as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic? (1-7 scale; 1=extremely unlikely, 7=extremely likely)
How likely do you think it is that someone you know will die as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic? (1-7 scale; 1=extremely unlikely, 7=extremely likely)
Are there currently any cases of COVID-19 in the city where you live? (Yes, No, Not sure) 
Has anyone you know personally tested positive for coronavirus? (Yes, No, Not sure)
Are you currently social/physical distancing? (Staying home whenever possible, avoiding contact with others, maintaining at least 6 feet of distance from anyone you aren’t living with.) (Yes, Somewhat, No) 
How long have you been social distancing? Please input your answer in days. (open field) 

Demographic information (gender, race, ethnicity, age, state and county location) 
Socioeconomic status (measured with questions about family income, parents’ education level, current occupation, current income, worries about finances, qualifying for financial aid, etc.)

Risky decision making. Our analysis approach will focus on fitting participants’ choices of risky or safe options as a function of the values present on the current and recent trials. Specifically, we will leverage advanced Bayesian hierarchical linear and nonlinear modeling procedures (i.e. mixed-effects logistic linear regression using the packages lme4 and/or brms in R; sampling-based estimation of prospect-theory inspired nonlinear models using Markov-Chain Monte Carlo [MCMC] procedures in Stan) to separately and simultaneously account for multiple different cognitive processes underlying risky decision-making, including risk attitudes (feelings about chance), loss aversion (relative weight of losses versus gains), choice consistency (randomness in the decision process), decision bias (a value-independent bias to choose risky or safe outcomes). This approach will also enable us to pool data across participants while still allowing individuals to vary, thus maximizing our statistical power. We will correlate individual differences measures of perceived stress, state or trait anxiety, loneliness, and/or pandemic perception, as well as objective measures of pandemic progression like the number of confirmed infections or deaths with the parameter estimates across people, as well as enter these variables directly as covariates into the linear and non-linear models. 

AX-CPT. Accuracy rates and median correct reaction times for each trial condition (AX, AY, BX, BX) will be calculated and examined using repeated-measures ANOVA. An inverse efficiency measure combining both accuracy and reaction time (Bruyer & Brysbaert, 2011) will also be calculated for each trial condition and examined using parallel ANOVA analyses. Significant effects will be followed up with pairwise comparisons.  

We will also compute a proactive index, a composite behavioral variable measuring relative tendency toward proactive control (following Chiew & Braver, 2014), for the same three metrics of behavior: accuracy rates, reaction times, and inverse efficiency measures. The proactive index will be used as an outcome variable in multiple regression analyses with pandemic progression (number of cases and number of deaths), state anxiety, trait anxiety, perceived stress, and loneliness as outcome predictors.

q19.value:
Risky decision-making: For linear model fits, we will use conventional statistical thresholds of p < 0.05 when evaluating beta estimates. For nonlinear computational models, we will use likelihood ratio tests to evaluate components of maximum likelihood-estimated models with a standard p value of p < 0.05, and we will use 95% confidence intervals with the Markov-Chain Monte-Carlo (MCMC) samples produced by Bayesian estimation methods.

AX-CPT: For evaluating results of ANOVA and multiple regression analyses, we will use conventional statistical thresholds of p < .05 and two-tailed tests.

q20.value: Data will be excluded if participants fail attention checks or fail to understand behavioral task instructions. Task performance <= 3 standard deviations below mean performance may be considered evidence of failure to understand the task and constitute grounds for exclusion. AX-CPT task trials with reaction times under 200ms will be excluded from analysis.

q21.value: Missing data will be excluded from analyses. Sample sizes for each analysis will be specified accordingly in the text of the eventual manuscript.

q22.value:
Social contact questions: We will examine how individual differences in social contact (and differences between January and current social contact) are related to measures of pandemic progression, anxiety, perceived stress, and loneliness. We will also examine whether individual differences in social contact predict experimental task performance above and beyond the measures used in confirmatory analyses using hierarchical regression. 

Perception of and behaviors toward the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic: We will examine how individual differences in COVID-19 perceptions and behaviors are related to measures of pandemic progression, anxiety, perceived stress, and loneliness. We will also examine whether individual differences in these perceptions and behaviors predict experimental task performance above and beyond the measures used in confirmatory analyses using hierarchical regression. 

Demographic and socioeconomic status questions: We will examine how demographic factors and socioeconomic status are related to measures of experimental task performance, stress, anxiety and loneliness. We will also examine whether demographic factors and socioeconomic status moderate the influence of pandemic progression, stress, anxiety, and loneliness on task performance. 

Affective state as a mediator of pandemic progression’s effect on choice and cognitive performance: We will conduct mediation analyses to examine whether the relationship between pandemic progression and task performance outcomes is mediated by measures of stress, anxiety, depression, social contact, and perceptions/behaviors towards the COVID-19 pandemic.

attributes.title: Outdoor Use, Personality, Wellness, and Smoking
attributes.description: This is an extension of our project in response to the novel coronavirus outbreak.

summary.value: In light of the outbreak of COVID-19, we would like to investigate the role that EcoWellness, access to nature, and individual differences (e.g., HEXACO personality, depression, anxiety) play in response to the outbreak and perceived susceptibility. This study will be largely exploratory, as it is being conducted during the outbreak, but will build on previous findings from the other registrations associated with this project in the sense that this project may give us better insight as to how EcoWellness can be a protective factor. In terms of design, this will be a correlational study run through Amazon's Mechanical Turk (MTurk) and the analyses will follow this correlational design. We will start with a series of bivariate correlations and depending on these findings, we may conduct regression or SEM analyses to get a better sense of how EcoWellness acts as a protective factor.

q1.value: Anticipatory suppression of tactile stimulation with interfering body-internal and -external action effects

q3.value: When manipulating a distal object (e.g. a tool) it can happen that this object moves in ways that are spatially incompatible with the body movements controlling these object movements. This is for example the case when moving a pivotal lever with one's hand where the effective end of the lever is always moving in the oppposite direction than the hand. While it has been shown that such situations can lead to worse performance in terms of reaction times or error rates compared to situations where body movement and object movement are spatially compatible, this often does not lead to noticeable conscious challenges for people when performing such movements. It has been suggested that this might be because people suppress their body representations in this situation and focus to a greater extent on the object so that the conflict between the inverted movements wold be reduced. We want to find empirical support for this idea by letting participants perform predictably compatible or incompatible actions and let them judge the experienced strength of tactile stimulations during the phase of movement planning on the effective body part.

q4.value:
We expect that tactile stimulations prior to the movement are experienced as less intense on the effective hand than on the inactive hand when hand and object movement are incompatible, but not when they are compatible:
- The point of subjective equality for the stimulation on the active hand feeling just as strong as on the inactive hand should be higher in the incompatible than in the compatible situation and this should be specific for time windows of less than 150 ms before movement onset

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Participants will perform a reaction time task with an additional tactile judgment task. Based on the color of a visual stimulus they will have to move that stimulus either into a left or right goal box on the computer screen (or not move at all in the case of a NoGo-Stimulus). The experiment will consist of two sessions. In one session. participants will have to move the stimulus with a right hand mouse movement in the same direction (compatible) and in the other session with a mouse movement in the opposite direction (incompatible). Furthermore, shortly after the presentation of the color stimulus, participants will experience tactile stimulations of 14 different intensities on both hands and they will be asked to judge after every movement whether the stimulation on the right or left hand felt stronger. The time point of these stimulations will be chosen in a way that it will occur before participants have the chance to react upon the stimulus and will be adjusted adaptively in every trial to try to create a relatively equally distributed range of stimulation time points up to 350 ms before movement onset.

q9.value:
The order of sessions will be counterbalanced between participants.
The stimulus-response mapping will be counterbalanced between participants.
The order of trials per session will be randomized regarding the combination of the different stimulation intensities on the right and left hand.
After every trial, the trial will be classified into one out of four categories depending on the time of the stimulation: 0-100 ms before movement onset, 101-200 ms before movement onset, 201-300 ms before movement onset and over 300 ms before movement onset. For every new trial, the program will try to produce a time point that will lead to a classification in the category with the at that point lowest number of trials by substracting a random number out of the range of that category from the mean reaction time of the last ten trials.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants can sign up for the study using an online platform used for this purpose. They have to be between 18 and 40 years of age, have no known neurological or psychiatric diseases, have normal or corrected-to-normal vision and be fluent in German in order to understand the task instructions. They will be payed 20 Euros in total for participating in two sesssions of one hour each on two concesuctive days. registration_responses.q1: Anticipatory suppression of tactile stimulation with interfering body-internal and -external action effects
registration_responses.q3: When manipulating a distal object (e.g. a tool) it can happen that this object moves in ways that are spatially incompatible with the body movements controlling these object movements. This is for example the case when moving a pivotal lever with one's hand where the effective end of the lever is always moving in the oppposite direction than the hand. While it has been shown that such situations can lead to worse performance in terms of reaction times or error rates compared to situations where body movement and object movement are spatially compatible, this often does not lead to noticeable conscious challenges for people when performing such movements. It has been suggested that this might be because people suppress their body representations in this situation and focus to a greater extent on the object so that the conflict between the inverted movements wold be reduced. We want to find empirical support for this idea by letting participants perform predictably compatible or incompatible actions and let them judge the experienced strength of tactile stimulations during the phase of movement planning on the effective body part.
registration_responses.q4:
We expect that tactile stimulations prior to the movement are experienced as less intense on the effective hand than on the inactive hand when hand and object movement are incompatible, but not when they are compatible:
- The point of subjective equality for the stimulation on the active hand feeling just as strong as on the inactive hand should be higher in the incompatible than in the compatible situation and this should be specific for time windows of less than 150 ms before movement onset
q6: No blinding is involved in this study.

The order of sessions will be counterbalanced between participants.
The stimulus-response mapping will be counterbalanced between participants.
The order of trials per session will be randomized regarding the combination of the different stimulation intensities on the right and left hand.
After every trial, the trial will be classified into one out of four categories depending on the time of the stimulation: 0-100 ms before movement onset, 101-200 ms before movement onset, 201-300 ms before movement onset and over 300 ms before movement onset. For every new trial, the program will try to produce a time point that will lead to a classification in the category with the at that point lowest number of trials by substracting a random number out of the range of that category from the mean reaction time of the last ten trials.

registration_responses.q8.question: Participants will perform a reaction time task with an additional tactile judgment task. Based on the color of a visual stimulus they will have to move that stimulus either into a left or right goal box on the computer screen (or not move at all in the case of a NoGo-Stimulus). The experiment will consist of two sessions. In one session. participants will have to move the stimulus with a right hand mouse movement in the same direction (compatible) and in the other session with a mouse movement in the opposite direction (incompatible). Furthermore, shortly after the presentation of the color stimulus, participants will experience tactile stimulations of 14 different intensities on both hands and they will be asked to judge after every movement whether the stimulation on the right or left hand felt stronger. The time point of these stimulations will be chosen in a way that it will occur before participants have the chance to react upon the stimulus and will be adjusted adaptively in every trial to try to create a relatively equally distributed range of stimulation time points up to 350 ms before movement onset.

attributes.title: Metanalysis of eye-movements deficits in psychotic patients
attributes.description: This study aims to shed new light on the use of Eye Movements Disorders (EMD) as an informative biomarker for psychiatric disorders. Although EMD are one of the most replicated deficits in the psychiatric literature (Franco et al., 2014), the strong heterogeneity of results is still an unexplained issue that could be effectively addressed with a quantitative review of evidence, i.e. a metanalysis. The importance of metanalysis is increasingly stressed in the era of the replication crisis in psychology, as it provides more precise estimates of an original study or claim, and can contribute to theoretical advance by identifying new relations among variables (Cumming, 2014; Cumming and Calin-Jageman, 2016).

q1.value: Eye Movements Disorders in Psychiatric Patients: a metanalysis

q2.value: Sara Garofalo, Mariagrazia Benassi, Sara Giovagnoli, Matteo Orsoni, Silvia Dal Col, Chiara Ruscelli

q3.value:
This study aims to shed new light on the use of Eye Movements Disorders (EMD) as an informative biomarker for psychiatric disorders. Although EMD are one of the most replicated deficits in the psychiatric literature (Franco et al., 2014), the strong heterogeneity of results is still an unexplained issue that could be effectively addressed with a quantitative review of evidence, i.e. a metanalysis. The importance of metanalysis is increasingly stressed in the era of the replication crisis in psychology, as it provides more precise estimates of an original study or claim, and can contribute to theoretical advance by identifying new relations among variables (Cumming, 2014; Cumming and Calin-Jageman, 2016).
At present, two metanalyses are available on this topic. A first one (Heinrichs, 2004) provided a single effect size on eye-movement deficits, as part of a much larger meta-analysis on the neurocognitive deficits accompanying schizophrenia, and it included only 14 studies. A second one (O’Driscoll and Callahan, 2008) introduced the importance of considering other features of the patient’s population but only included demographics or major clinical characteristics (like age, duration of illness, and severity of symptoms).

q4.value: The aim of the present study is to provide new evidence on the role of EMD in schizophrenia and bipolar disorder patients. This will be achieved with a large-scale metanalytic study that will analyze the magnitude (i.e., effect size) of (a) the difference in eye movements performance between psychiatric patients (schizophrenia and bipolar disorder) and healthy controls, and (b) the relation between patient’s symptoms severity and EMD. We expect to collect a large number of studies that will allow having a well-founded meta-analytical study. The neuro-cognitive profile, clinical characteristics and pharmacological treatment will be considered as a possible mediator of the heterogeneity of results.

q5.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
The meta-analysis will be conducted following the methods and principles of Cumming and colleagues (Cumming 2014; Cumming and Calin-Jageman 2016). 
Searches will be conducted on two main digital databases, PubMed and PsycInfo. The keywords schizophrenia, psychosis, psychotic, and bipolar will be used in combination with: eye-movement, eye tracking, oculomotor, smooth pursuit, saccade, antisaccade, gain, fixation, electrooculography, electrooculogram, infrared oculography, eye-movement dysfunction, and eye-tracking. The relevance of identified articles will be first judged by inspection of title and abstract. The reference lists of all retrieved articles will be inspected to identify possibly omitted studies. The twenty most active investigators in the area will be contacted and asked to identify missing studies and to provide information about unpublished/non-significant results, to contrast the “file drawer effect”.

q10.value: Registration prior to any human observation of the data

question.value: For each study, the following domains of characteristics will be acquired: study (e.g., title, year, journal, authors), participants (e.g., diagnosis, sample size), methods (e.g., recording method, target waveform, task), statistical analysis (group comparison or correlation analysis, statistical approach, mean, sd, significance, effect size), dependent measure (i.e., eye-movement measure), clinical characteristics (e.g., duration of illness, severity of symptoms), neurocognitive profile (e.g., IQ, cognitive tests), pharmacology (e.g., CPZ equivalent dosage).

q13.value:
After a preliminary inspection, the expected number of candidate articles will be around 1000. 
Of these, included articles will: be methodologically correct; be written in English; have investigated eye movements in psychotic, schizophrenia, or bipolar patients; not include data from previous studies; not include groups of patients with mixed diagnoses; include sufficient data to calculate an effect size. If insufficient information is presented, a request will be sent to the corresponding author.

question.value:
For each study, the following domains of characteristics will be acquired: study (e.g., title, year, journal, authors), participants (e.g., diagnosis, sample size), methods (e.g., recording method, target waveform, task), statistical analysis (group comparison or correlation analysis, statistical approach, mean, sd, significance, effect size), dependent measure (i.e., eye-movement measure), clinical characteristics (e.g., duration of illness, severity of symptoms), neurocognitive profile (e.g., IQ, cognitive tests), pharmacology (e.g., CPZ equivalent dosage). 
The neuro-cognitive profile, clinical characteristics and pharmacological treatment will be considered as a possible mediator of the heterogeneity of results where available.

Different effect size indexes will be calculated for all the studies to have comparable measures. Effect sizes will be averaged separately for group difference studies and for correlational studies. 
The homogeneity test will be applied to examine the variability of effect sizes across studies. When significant heterogeneity is found, potential moderator variables will be tested (demographics, socio-economic, pharmacotherapy, cognitive measures, outcomes, and clinical information).
To measure the impact of heterogeneity, different indexes will be used, namely Q, H, R, and I2 (Doi et al. 2015; Huedo-Medina et al. 2006). Interpretation and interval estimate of these measures will be critically compared. 
Studies will be grouped based on the compatibility of the data contained, in terms of population, task type, recording method, etc.

q22.value: Excluded articles articles will NOT: be methodologically correct; be written in English; have investigated eye movements in psychotic, schizophrenia, or bipolar patients; not include data from previous studies; not include groups of patients with mixed diagnoses; include sufficient data to calculate an effect size. If insufficient information is presented, a request will be sent to the corresponding author.

q23.value: The reference lists of all retrieved articles will be inspected to identify possibly omitted studies. The twenty most active investigators in the area will be contacted and asked to identify missing studies and to provide information about unpublished/non-significant results, to contrast the “file drawer effect”.

attributes.title: Cost-utility analysis in chronic kidney disease patients awaiting kidney transplant; what pays? A systematic review protocol
attributes.description: Health systems are under pressure to deliver more effective care without expansion of resources.  This is particularly pertinent to diseases like chronic kidney disease (CKD) that are exacting a substantial financial burden to many health systems.  The aim of this study is to systematically review the Cost Utility Analysis (CUA) evidence generated across interventions for CKD patients undergoing kidney transplant.

summary.value:
Health systems are under pressure to deliver more effective care without expansion of resources.  This is particularly pertinent to diseases like chronic kidney disease (CKD) that are exacting substantial financial burden to many health systems.  However, cost-effective evidence of kidney transplant related practices are currently lacking.  

Therefore, the aim of this study is to systematically review the Cost-Utility Analysis(CUA) evidence generated across interventions for CKD patients undergoing kidney transplant.  This registration contains the protocol of the proposed systematic review.

registration_responses.summary:
Health systems are under pressure to deliver more effective care without expansion of resources.  This is particularly pertinent to diseases like chronic kidney disease (CKD) that are exacting substantial financial burden to many health systems.  However, cost-effective evidence of kidney transplant related practices are currently lacking.  

Therefore, the aim of this study is to systematically review the Cost-Utility Analysis(CUA) evidence generated across interventions for CKD patients undergoing kidney transplant.  This registration contains the protocol of the proposed systematic review.

attributes.title: Replication of Ferguson and Sheldon (2013): The importance of intent for altering mood
attributes.description: Positive stimulus with intention leads to positive affect

q1.value: Jesenia Medina, Antonio Mora-Salcedo, Laura Sanchez, Andrea Sicairos

q2.value: Does the presence of a set intention improve happiness when given positive poetry? We hypothesize that participants who are in the intentional condition will have an actual increase in happiness.

q3.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.
Personnel who analyze the data collected from the study are not aware of the treatment applied to any given group.
Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)

question.value: This will be a mix design. Participants will be randomly assigned to intention conditions (Intention) and (no intention). Everyone will experience the positive poetry.

q7.value: This is a simple randomization. Qualtrics will randomly assign conditions to the participants.

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: A convenience sample of students at the Midwestern liberal arts college, Dominican University, will be our participants. Participants will receive a credit towards research participation requirements.

q11.value: Sample goal is 418 participants, which is 2.5x the original sample size of 167.

q12.value: Using Simonsohn’s guideline (2015) of gathering 2.5x the original sample size, we determined that to ensure good power we would need 418 participants.

q13.value: We will stop collecting data when the sample size target is met or until we run out of time to complete the experiment.

question.value: For this study we will have one manipulated variable with two levels. The first manipulated level is with intention and the other level i with no intention. All participants will be exposed to positive poetry.

Measured variables for this study will be mood improvement after reading poetry with no or high intention.
Slider bar happiness indicator - self- reported from 1 (very negative) to 100 (very positive)
Self determination Theory - self reported on a scale from 1 (being not at all) to 5 (being to a great extent)
Emmons (1991) short list of affect terms – self-reported on a scale from 1 (being not at all) to 15 (being extremely)
Manipulation check-  To what extent did you intend or try to feel happy from 1 (being not at all) to 5 (being to a great extent)
Demographics variables – age, gender identity and ethnicity.

Does the presence of a set intention to be happy improve actual happiness when given either positive or negative stimulus?
We will do a mean difference in Jamovi analysis

q19.value: We will use the standard p<.05 criteria for determining if the ANOVA and the post hoc test suggest that the results are significantly different from those expected if the null hypothesis were correct.

q20.value:
Any participants who failed the manipulation check were excluded; participants were asked “To what extent will you intend or try to feel happier while listening to the music?” on a likert scale (1 = Not at all to 5 = To a great extent). Those within the high intentions condition should respond high on the scale while those in the low intentions condition should report lower on the scale.
Those who had technical difficulties will also have their data excluded.

q21.value: Responses collected that have missing data will be excluded from analysis.

Demographics variables – age, gender identity and ethnicity.

summary.value:
Study Information 

Title: Contrasting two models of utilitarian moral judgments  

Authors: Rea Antoniou, Heather Romero-Kornblum, Winston Chiong
 
Research Questions: 

Aim: To test hypotheses derived from two competing models of the cognitive bases of utilitarian moral judgment. 

    In social neuroscience, there has been particular interest in understanding the neural bases of human moral cognition. An organizing focus of this research has been the contrast between utilitarian and non-utilitarian (particularly, deontological) modes of moral reasoning. One influential model of this contrast is the dual process theory advocated by Greene and colleagues (Greene, Nystrom, Engell, Darley, & Cohen, 2004;  Greene & Haidt, 2002; Paxton, Ungar, & Greene, 2012), informed by broader dual process models of "intuitive" fast judgments and "deliberative" slow judgments (Gilovich, Griffin & Kahneman, 2002). On this account, characteristically deontological judgments are driven by automatic emotional responses, while characteristically utilitarian judgments are driven by controlled cognitive processes. 

    However, an alternative account of utilitarian judgment has been proposed by Kahane and colleagues (Kahane, Everett, Earp, Caviola, Faber, Crockett, &  Savulescu, 2018; Kahane, Everett, Earp, Farias, & Savulescu, 2015). On this two-dimensional model, the two dimensions referenced do not refer (as in Greene's dual process model) to contrasting cognitive processes believed to respectively underlie deontology and utilitarianism, but instead to dissociable components within utilitarian judgment itself. That is, while Greene's dual process theory proposes that utilitarian judgments result from a single, unitary psychological pattern, this model proposes two dimensions: absence of constraints against instrumental harm (the negative dimension) and impartial beneficence (the positive dimension). Kahane and colleagues have presented evidence that these two dimensions of utilitarianism are not associated in the lay population; i.e., willingness to endorse harm in hypothetical moral dilemmas is not indicative of impartial concern for the greater good. 

    Kahane and colleagues' primary focus in the positive dimension is on utilitarian requirements for self-sacrifice when the agent's personal interests conflict with the greater good--linked to the philosophical characterization of utilitarianism as demanding. However, commonsense morality (and many varieties of deontology) encompasses both agent-centered permissions, in which one is permitted but not required to favor one's own interests over others, and special obligations, in which one is positively required to favor the interests of relations and those otherwise related to one over strangers (Parfit, 1984; Scheffler, 1994). On a two-dimensional model, utilitarian judgments contrary to agent-centered permissions and special obligations would both reflect a common positive dimension of impartial concern for the greater good that is dissociable from a negative dimension of willingness to instrumentally harm. Meanwhile, on the one-dimensional model of utilitarianism proposed in Greene's dual-process theory, tendencies to utilitarian judgment in all domains of conflict with commonsense morality (those involving personal rights, agent-centered permissions, and special obligations) all reflect controlled cognitive processes resulting in deliberate cost-benefit reasoning.

    We propose a study utilizing an existing research platform enrolling healthy older adults to test the predictions of these competing models. Our instrument includes dilemmas involving three domains of conflict between utilitarian judgment and commonsense morality, characterized according to conceptual categories and reviewed for content by two university professors of moral philosophy: agent-centered permissions (AP), special obligations (SO), and personal rights (PR, often referred to in the literature as cases involving "sacrificial harm"). This instrument also includes post-decision questions for each dilemma assessing perceived confidence, difficulty and emotion elicitation, as well as a control question to assess participants' understanding of the scenario. 

Hypotheses tested will be derived from two competing models:

Dual process theory (Greene)
- Hypothesis A1: At the subject level, neuropsychological measures of cognitive control are positively associated with more utilitarian judgments across all three moral categories tested. 
- Hypothesis A2: Post-decision self-reports of emotion elicitation are negatively associated with utilitarian judgments across all three moral categories tested. 
- Hypothesis A3: At the subject level, utilitarian judgments across all three categories (personal rights, agent-centered permissions, and special obligations) are positively associated.

Two-dimensional model (Kahane)
- Hypothesis B1: At the subject level, more utilitarian judgments in dilemmas involving agent-centered permissions are positively associated with more utilitarian judgments in dilemmas involving special obligations. 
- Hypothesis B2: At the subject level, there is no positive association between more utilitarian judgments in dilemmas involving personal rights, and more utilitarian judgments in dilemmas involving either special obligations or agent-centered permissions (i.e., negative or no association).

Exploratory
- Hypothesis C1: Dorsolateral prefrontal grey matter volumes are positively associated with more utilitarian judgments across all three moral categories tested. 
- Hypothesis C2: Ventromedial prefrontal grey matter volumes are negatively associated with more utilitarian judgments across all three moral categories tested.

Sampling Plan:

Existing data
    Some task data for this study (127 participants) were collected during an initial piloting phase for our online platform; while descriptive statistical analyses were performed on responses for purposes of platform testing, cognitive/behavioral tests of these preregistered or other hypotheses have not been performed on the data. We will utilize a new opportunity to collect further task data in an expanded cohort of older adults prior to performing the analyses described below. Of note, participants for this study will be recruited from a longitudinal cohort of healthy older adults that includes existing neuroimaging and neuropsychological data, which will be utilized in the analyses described.

    Also of note, in the process of planning for the second wave, a worldwide outbreak of a novel coronavirus (COVID-19) infection occurred. This environmental event is likely to introduce heterogeneity between waves, although for many of the hypotheses tested this heterogeneity may or may not influence the magnitude of hypothesized associations between variables. (For instance, in Hypothesis A3, if utilitarian judgments result from a single unitary psychological pattern, then even if there is a main effect of wave on this pattern, the hypothesized associations among judgments in three domains should still hold.) Measures to assess and control for such heterogeneity are described in the analyses and sensitivity analyses described.

Data collection procedures
    Neurologically healthy, community dwelling older adults will be included from a cohort at the UCSF Memory and Aging Center that includes in-person measurements and online web-based behavioral tasks. Participants included in this cohort are assessed as neurologically normal on the basis of informant interview, neurological examination and cognitive testing. Members of this cohort received or will receive an e-mail inviting them to participate in an online instrument that includes the moral reasoning task described below. 

Sample size 
    In the initial wave of data collection, behavioral data were collected from 127 from our longitudinal cohort of healthy older adults. In the planned second wave of data collection, we aim to collect behavioral data from an additional 150 older adults, for a total sample of 277.  
  
    Because our online data collection is not synchronized with in-person standard neuropsychological and neuroimaging measures, we will use an algorithm to link participants' task responses to available data from in-person testing. These in-person measures are collected on each participant in the cohort at roughly 2-½-year intervals. We will limit the linkage of associated neuropsychological and neuroimaging tests to those acquired within 1-½ years of behavioral task performance. This will limit the effective sample size for testing Hypotheses A1, C1 and C2. Based on existing data for wave 1 and data collection patterns for wave 2, we anticipate linked neuropsychological data for hypothesis A1 for 235 participants. We anticipate linked neuroimaging data for hypotheses C1 and C2 for 113 participants. 

Sample size rationale
    
Hypothesis A1:
    Standard power calculations for an expected correlation coefficient of 0.2 at the low end would yield power of 0.87 (n = 235, two-sided, alpha = 0.05 level).
 
Hypotheses A2, A3, and B1:
    Standard power calculations for an expected correlation coefficient of -0.2 (Hypothesis A2) or 0.2 (Hypotheses A3 and B1) at the low end would yield power of 0.92 (n = 277, two-sided, alpha = 0.05 level).
 
Hypothesis B2:
    Based on an assumption of either no effect or a weak effect, standard power calculations assuming power of .8 for a sample of 277 participants correspond to correlation coefficients of 0.17 or -0.17 (two-sided, alpha = 0.05 level).
 
Hypotheses C1 and C2:
    Standard power calculations assuming power of .8 for a sample of 113 participants correspond to a correlation coefficient of 0.26 (two-sided, alpha = 0.05 level).

Variables:

Measured variables

Moral reasoning task
    In this task, participants read and answer a set of 24 dilemmatic vignettes, which encompass 3 moral categories. 
1. The Personal Rights (PR) category is composed of 8 items concerning choices that would substantially affect the interests of other people, and in which the best overall outcome could only be produced by violating an individual’s personal rights. For instance, whether to push one person into the path of a runaway trolley that would otherwise kill five people. Here, the utilitarian choice is to sacrifice the lesser number of people to produce the greatest welfare.
2. The Agent-centered Permissions (AP) category is composed of 8 items characterized as choices that assess one’s attitude toward improving others' welfare at cost to one’s own interests. For example, whether to make a donation or keep the money for one’s own personal use. In this category, the utilitarian choice reflects disregard of self interest for the greater good. 
3. The Special Obligation (SO) category is composed of 8 items concerning choices that assess one’s attitude toward the favoring of family members, friends, or close others at the cost of the greatest expected welfare. For example, the parental choices that prioritize one's own child's well-being over the well-being of other children. Here, utilitarian judgements reflect disregard of tight social bonds for the greater good.

    To ensure task comprehension, after each dilemma participants are presented a control question asking them to correctly indicate the meaning of the dilemma (binary format yes/no). Participants’ responses will be excluded from the analysis if they choose incorrect responses in 7 or more out of 24 control trials. Within each moral dilemma, three additional questions (ratings) are included: confidence of the decision (“How confident are you that this was the right choice?” Likert-scaled 1-5), difficulty of the decision (“How difficult did you find this decision?” Likert-scaled 1-5) and emotion elicited by the decision (“How emotional were you when thinking about the situation?” Likert-scaled 1-5).

    Each response will be binary coded as either utilitarian (1) or non-utilitarian (-1). Furthermore, there is a difference between a response in which a participant gives a utilitarian response (e.g., killing one to save five) and perceives little difficulty, and a response in which a participant gives a utilitarian response but experiences significant conflict. Intuitively, the first response exhibits a more strongly utilitarian tendency than the latter. For each response, a utilitarian or non-utilitarian (1 or -1) response will be scaled by a factor of (6 - difficulty)/5; thus, a utilitarian response of minimal difficulty will be scored as 1*(6-1)/5 = 1, a utilitarian response of maximal difficulty will be scored as 1*(6-5)/5 = 0.2, a non-utilitarian response of maximal difficulty will be scored as -1*(6-5)/5 = -0.2, and a non-utilitarian response of minimal difficulty will be scored as -1*(6-1)/5 = -1. The score for each category will be the sum of scores of responses to dilemmas of that category. 

Cognitive control
    Utilizing standard neuropsychological measures collected as part of participants' involvement in a longitudinal cohort study of aging, we will generate a cognitive control score as the mean of standardized scores for a Stroop interference task, a modified Trails task, and dysexecutive errors.

Neuroimaging data
    Neuroimaging analyses will utilize FreeSurfer-extracted volumes from T1 structural scans collected as part of this cohort's research involvement at our center. 

Behavioral analyses
    The individual hypotheses tested are non-independent: some are predictions from the dual-process account and others from the two-dimensional model. As our aim is to assess the relative support for either model in our experiment, all hypotheses will first be individually evaluated at a nominal p value of 0.05. 

    For hypotheses A3, B1 and B2 we will conduct pairwise correlations among participants' category scores for PR, AP and SO dilemmas. 

    For hypothesis A1, we will examine the association of the cognitive control summary score with the total utilitarian judgment score summed across all categories (PR, AP, SO), controlling for participant age, gender, educational attainment and wave. In addition, a second model will be created, adding as another predictor an interaction term between the cognitive control summary score and wave. Model comparison (via the R anova() function) will be performed to test whether the second model significantly reduces the residual sum of squares; if so, then the second model will be used to test the hypothesis, while if not then the first model will be used to test the hypothesis.

    For hypothesis A2, we will construct a two-level mixed-effects model testing the association of item-level utilitarian judgment scores and emotion elicitation scores across all categories (PR, AP, SO), with items grouped by participant. Items in which participants gave incorrect responses to the control question will be omitted. At the subject level this model will be controlled for participant age, gender, educational attainment and wave. In addition, as for hypothesis A1, a second model will be created, adding as another predictor an interaction term between emotion elicitation scores and wave. As for hypothesis A1, model comparison will be performed to test whether the second model significantly reduces the residual sum of squares; if so, then the second model will be used to test the hypothesis, while if not then the first model will be used to test the hypothesis.

Neuroimaging analyses
    For hypotheses C1 and C2, we will examine the association of extracted FreeSurfer grey matter volumes for dlPFC and vmPFC with the total utilitarian judgment score summed across all categories (PR, AP, SO) in general linear models controlling for participant age, gender, educational attainment and wave. In addition, as for hypotheses A1-A2, for each model a second model will be created, adding as another predictor an interaction term between the utilitarian judgment score and wave. As for hypotheses A1-A2, model comparison will be performed to test whether the second model significantly reduces the residual sum of squares; if so, then the second model will be used to test the hypothesis, while if not then the first model will be used to test the hypothesis. 

Sensitivity analyses
    As sensitivity analyses, we will repeat the primary analyses using binary (-1 and 1) utilitarian judgment scores for each dilemma without scaling. We will also repeat the analyses for hypothesis A1, A2, C1 and C2 for each category independently (PR, AP, SO). We will analyze all hypotheses in the two waves separately. We will also repeat the primary analyses with all excluded data re-included. 

Data Exclusion
    As above, we will exclude data from participants that incorrectly answered 7 or more control questions, and in item-level analyses (hypothesis A2) we will exclude responses in which participants gave incorrect responses to the subsequent control question. 

References

Gilovich, T., Griffin, D., & Kahneman, D. (Eds.). (2002). Heuristics and biases: The psychology 
    of intuitive judgment. Cambridge university press.

Greene, J., & Haidt, J. (2002). How (and where) does moral judgment work?. Trends in 
    cognitive sciences, 6(12), 517-523.

Greene, J. D., Nystrom, L. E., Engell, A. D., Darley, J. M., & Cohen, J. D. (2004). The neural bases 
    of cognitive conflict and control in moral judgment. Neuron, 44(2), 389-400.

Greene, J. D., Sommerville, R. B., Nystrom, L. E., Darley, J. M., & Cohen, J. D. (2001). An fMRI 
    investigation of emotional engagement in moral judgment. Science, 293(5537), 2105–2108. 
    https://doi.org/10.1126/science.1062872

Kahane, G., Everett, J. A., Earp, B. D., Farias, M., & Savulescu, J. (2015). ‘Utilitarian’ judgments 
    in sacrificial moral dilemmas do not reflect impartial concern for the greater good. 
    Cognition, 134, 193-209.

Kahane, G., Everett, J. A. C., Earp, B. D., Caviola, L., Faber, N. S., Crockett, M. J., & Savulescu, J. 
    (2018). Beyond sacrificial harm: A two-dimensional model of utilitarian psychology. 
    Psychological Review, 125(2), 131–164. https://doi.org/10.1037/rev0000093

Parfit, D. (1984). Reasons and persons. OUP Oxford.

Paxton, J. M., Ungar, L., & Greene, J. D. (2012). Reflection and reasoning in moral judgment. 

Scheffler, S. (1994). The rejection of consequentialism: A philosophical investigation of the 
    considerations underlying rival moral conceptions. Oxford University Press.

Sensitivity analyses
    As sensitivity analyses, we will repeat the primary analyses using binary (-1 and 1) utilitarian judgment scores for each dilemma without scaling. We will also repeat the analyses for hypothesis A1, A2, C1 and C2 for each category independently (PR, AP, SO). We will analyze all hypotheses in the two waves separately. We will also repeat the primary analyses with all excluded data re-included. 

Data Exclusion
    As above, we will exclude data from participants that incorrectly answered 7 or more control questions, and in item-level analyses (hypothesis A2) we will exclude responses in which participants gave incorrect responses to the subsequent control question.

    cognitive sciences, 6(12), 517-523.

attributes.description: Utilitarian moral reasoning in times of a global health crisis

summary.value:
Study Information 

Title: Utilitarian moral reasoning in times of a global health crisis

Authors: Rea Antoniou, Heather Romero-Kornblum, Winston Chiong

Research Questions: The effect of COVID-19 pandemic on utilitarian reasoning

Aim: To test hypotheses derived from terror management, socio-emotional selectivity, and dual process theories on utilitarian judgements within the context of the COVID-19 pandemic.

Introduction:

    Based on the dual process account of moral judgments (Greene, Nystrom, Engell, Darley, & Cohen, 2004; Greene & Haidt, 2002; Paxton, Ungar, & Greene, 2012), contexts that deprive an individual’s deliberative resources may affect inferences, judgments and decisions. Τhe specific context of mortality salience (i.e., being reminded of one’s own mortality) may function as one of these contexts and, hence, influence moral judgments. The current threat of the COVID-19 outbreak may provide naturally-induced mortality salience. Accordingly, older people who may be at higher risk for COVID-19 can be especially vulnerable to this effect.

    Terror management theory (TMT) postulates that cognitive defenses are triggered when thinking of one’s eventual death, as an attempt to manage the anxiety that is likely elicited by such a thought (Greenberg, Pyszczynski, & Solomon, 1986). The dual-process model of terror management theory (Hayes, Schimel, Arndt, & Faucher, 2010; Pyszczynski, Greenberg, & Solomon, 1999) proposes that a first attempt to actively suppress conscious thoughts of death depletes cognitive resources. Prior research drawing on TMT and dual theories of moral cognition suggests that individuals who are primed with thoughts of impending death are less likely to give utilitarian responses on conflict problems (Trémolière et al., 2012). According to the dual process account of moral cognition, employing cognitive resources in response to moral dilemmas is associated with heightened levels of emotionality (Greene & Haidt, 2002).

    In addition, TMT posits that reminders of one’s mortality drive more meaningful and value-aligned pursuits (Pyszczynski, Greenberg, & Goldenberg, 2003). In the wake of a realization that death can occur at any given time and without control, we seek to affirm the meaning of our existence (Pyszczynski et. al, 2006; Yetzer, Pyszczynski, & Greenberg, 2018). Similarly, according to socio-emotional selectivity theory (SST), priming of the fragility of life and narrowing time horizons shifts goal motivation of adults of all ages from future orientation to that of emotional relevance (Carstensen, 2006; Fung & Carstensen, 2006). While SST is rooted in the realization that one’s time is fleeting, and not specifically of one’s mortality, both TMT and SST describe the regulation of difficult, potentially threatening stimuli. Simply put, when reminded that we are mortal, that life is fleeting and finite, and our time limited, we gravitate towards experiences that can reinforce our values and bring us greater emotional meaning. Accordingly, TMT and SST may be relevant theories in consideration of how individuals approach responding to moral dilemmas, tilting the moral compass towards more value-based reasoning (less utilitarian).

    In light of this, we propose a study comparing responses to hypothetical moral dilemmas during current times of the 2020 COVID-19 pandemic to responses collected in 2014 to determine the impact of real-time existential threat on utilitarian judgments. We expect that participants who respond to moral dilemmas during the 2020 COVID-19 pandemic will respond in a less utilitarian manner, which according to dual process theory and TMT is associated with depletion of cognitive resources stemming from thoughts of one’s eventual death. Additionally, as bunkering down in one’s worldview may provide existential relief and lead to greater confidence in one’s values (Pyszczynski et al., 2006), we predict that current participants will rate their decisions as made with greater confidence. Last, as the current pandemic serves as a reminder of the fleeting nature of life and time, as a secondary hypothesis, we predict that ratings of the emotion elicited by the decisions will be higher, overall, among current participants, consistent with SST and dual process theories.

Primary hypotheses:
- Hypothesis 1: Participants will give fewer utilitarian responses to moral dilemmas during the 2020 COVID-19 pandemic than participants gave prior to this global health crisis.
- Hypothesis 2: Participants’ ratings of confidence in responding to the moral dilemmas during the 2020 COVID-19 pandemic will be higher compared to responses collected prior to this global health crisis.

Secondary hypothesis:
- Hypothesis 3: Participants’ ratings of emotional elicitation in responding to the moral dilemmas during the 2020 COVID-19 pandemic will be higher compared to responses collected in absence of this global health crisis.

Sampling Plan:

Existing data
    The 2014 wave of this study (127 participants) was collected during an initial piloting phase for our online platform; while descriptive statistical analyses were performed on responses for purposes of platform testing, cognitive/behavioral tests of these preregistered or other hypotheses have not been performed on the data. In the context of the 2020 COVID-19 pandemic, we propose to collect further data in an expanded cohort of older adults prior to performing the analyses described below. Participants for the 2020 wave will be recruited from the same longitudinal cohort of healthy older adults, with similar recruitment methods, as was used in the 2014 wave, but will be restricted to cohort members that did not participate in the 2014 wave. There will be other differences between the 2014 and 2020 waves, including superficial differences in questionnaire formatting and preliminary instructions. Participants in the 2014 wave received a $20 Amazon gift card for completing the instrument; given lack of current IRB approval for participant payment in the 2020 wave, this will be omitted in the 2020 wave.

Data collection procedures
    Neurologically healthy, community dwelling older adults will be included from a cohort at the UCSF Memory and Aging Center that includes in-person measurements and online web-based behavioral tasks. Participants included in this cohort are assessed as neurologically normal on the basis of informant interview, neurological examination and cognitive testing. Members of this cohort received or will receive an e-mail inviting them to participate in an online instrument that includes the moral reasoning task described below. 

Sample size 
    In the initial wave of data collection, behavioral data were collected from 127 from our longitudinal cohort of healthy older adults. In the planned second wave of data collection, we aim to collect behavioral data from an additional 150 older adults, for a total sample of 277.    

Sample size rationale
    Standard power calculations for a mean difference of - 0.3 or 0.3 at the low end would yield power of .8 (two-sided, n1 = 127, n2 = 150, alpha = 0.05 level).

Variables:

Measured variables

Moral reasoning task
    In this task, participants read and answer a set of 24 dilemmatic vignettes, which encompass 3 moral categories. 
1. The Personal Rights (PR) category is composed of 8 items concerning choices that would substantially affect the interests of other people, and in which the best overall outcome could only be produced by violating an individual’s personal rights. For instance, whether to push one person into the path of a runaway trolley that would otherwise kill five people. Here, the utilitarian choice is to sacrifice the lesser number of people to produce the greatest welfare.
2. The Agent-centered Permissions (AP) category is composed of 8 items characterized as choices that assess one’s attitude toward improving others' welfare at cost to one’s own interests. For example, whether to make a donation or keep the money for one’s own personal use. In this category, the utilitarian choice reflects disregard of self interest for the greater good. 
3. The Special Obligation (SO) category is composed of 8 items concerning choices that assess one’s attitude toward the favoring of family members, friends, or close others at the cost of the greatest expected welfare. For example, the parental choices that prioritize one's own child's well-being over the well-being of other children. Here, utilitarian judgements reflect disregard of tight social bonds for the greater good.

    To ensure task comprehension, after each dilemma participants are presented a control question asking them to correctly indicate the meaning of the dilemma (binary format yes/no). Participants’ responses will be excluded from the analysis if they choose incorrect responses in 7 or more out of 24 control trials. Within each moral dilemma, three additional questions (ratings) are included: confidence of the decision (“How confident are you that this was the right choice?” Likert-scaled 1-5), difficulty of the decision (“How difficult did you find this decision?” Likert-scaled 1-5) and emotion elicited by the decision (“How emotional were you when thinking about the situation?” Likert-scaled 1-5).

To be collected after participants respond to the moral dilemmas:
Questions from Kaiser Family Foundation poll, March 2020. 

    In the 2020 wave, we will also collect responses to questions about the impact of the COVID-19 outbreak. The first question is, "How worried, if at all, are you that you or someone in your family will get sick from the coronavirus?" The possible answers are: very worried, somewhat worried, not too worried, not at all worried, and don't know. Four questions will query whether the participant has taken any of the following actions in response to the coronavirus outbreak: Decided not to travel or changed travel plans; bought or worn a protective mask; stocked up on items such as food, household supplies, or prescription medications; stayed home instead of going to work, school, or other regular activities; canceled plans to attend large gatherings such as concerts or sporting events. These questions will be used to assess whether our 2020 wave was in fact affected by the COVID-19 outbreak, and in sensitivity analyses restricted to participants who describe themselves as affected.

Behavioral analyses
    The individual hypotheses tested are non-independent: these predictions are all informed by dual process accounts of moral reasoning, TMT, and SST. Thus, all hypotheses will first be individually evaluated at a nominal p value of 0.05, and all three analyses will be reported together.
    For hypothesis 1, for each participant we will sum their utilitarian responses across the PR, AP and SO categories. The sum of utilitarian responses will be entered as the outcome variable in a linear model with wave, age, gender and educational attainment as predictors. 
    For hypotheses 2 and 3, for each participant we will sum their confidence and emotion elicitation scores across the PR, AP, and SO moral categories. These scores will be entered as outcome variables in linear models with wave, age, gender and educational attainment as predictors.

Sensitivity analyses: 

    In one sensitivity analysis, we will repeat the primary analyses for hypotheses 1-3, but restricted to responses to PR dilemmas (which have been the main focus of dual process moral theories to date). In another sensitivity analysis, we will limit the wave 2 cohort to participants who either (1) described themselves as either very worried or somewhat worried about the coronavirus outbreak, or (2) have taken at least two of the five described possible responses to the coronavirus outbreak. Finally, we will repeat the primary analyses with all excluded data re-included.

Data exclusion:

    As above, we will exclude data from participants that incorrectly answered 7 or more control questions.

References

Carstensen, L. L. (2006). The influence of a sense of time on human development. Science, 
    312(5782), 1913-1915.

Fung, H. H., & Carstensen, L. L. (2006). Goals change when life's fragility is primed: Lessons 
    learned from older adults, the September 11 attacks and sars. Social Cognition, 24(3), 
    248–278.

Greene, J., & Haidt, J. (2002). How (and where) does moral judgment work?. Trends in 
    cognitive sciences, 6(12), 517-523.

Greene, J. D., Nystrom, L. E., Engell, A. D., Darley, J. M., & Cohen, J. D. (2004). The neural bases 
    of cognitive conflict and control in moral judgment. Neuron, 44(2), 389-400.

Greenberg, J., Pyszczynski, T., & Solomon, S. (1986). The causes and consequences of a need 
    for self-esteem: A terror management theory. In Public self and private self (pp. 189-212). 
    Springer, New York, NY.

Hayes, J., Schimel, J., Arndt, J., & Faucher, E. H. (2010). A theoretical and empirical review of 
    the death thought accessibility concept in terror management research. Psychological 
    bulletin, 136(5), 699.

Löckenhoff, C.E. and Carstensen, L.L. (2004), Socioemotional Selectivity Theory, Aging, and 
    Health: The Increasingly Delicate Balance Between Regulating Emotions and Making Tough 
    Choices. Journal of Personality, 72: 1395-1424.

Paxton, J. M., Ungar, L., & Greene, J. D. (2012). Reflection and reasoning in moral judgment. 
    Cognitive science, 36(1), 163-177.

Pyszczynski, T., Abdollahi, A., Solomon, S., Greenberg, J., Cohen, F., & Weise, D. (2006). 
    Mortality Salience, Martyrdom, and Military Might: The Great Satan Versus the Axis of Evil. 
    Personality and Social Psychology Bulletin, 32(4), 525–537.

Pyszczynski, T., Greenberg, J., & Goldenberg, J. L. (2003). Freedom versus fear: On the 
    defense, growth, and expansion of the self. In M. R. Leary & J. P. Tangney (Eds.), Handbook 
    of self and identity (p. 314–343). The Guilford Press.

Pyszczynski, T., Greenberg, J., & Solomon, S. (1999). A dual-process model of defense against 
    conscious and unconscious death-related thoughts: an extension of terror management 
    theory. Psychological review, 106(4), 835.

Trémolière, B., De Neys, W., & Bonnefon, J. F. (2012). Mortality salience and morality: Thinking 
    about death makes people less utilitarian. Cognition, 124(3), 379-384.

Yetzer, A. M., Pyszczynski, T., & Greenberg, J. (2018). A stairway to heaven: A terror 
    management theory perspective on morality. In K. Gray & J. Graham (Eds.), Atlas of moral 
    psychology (p. 241–251). The Guilford Press.
